column1: 1. The Border Patrol's routine stopping of a vehicle at a permanent checkpoint located on a major highway away from the Mexican border for brief questioning of the vehicle's occupants is consistent with the Fourth Amendment
column2: and the stops and questioning may be made at reasonably located checkpoints in the absence of any individualized suspicion that the particular vehicle contains illegal aliens.  Pp.  428 U. S. 556-564.

column1: (a) To require that such stops always be based on reasonable suspicion would be impractical because the flow of traffic tends to be too heavy to allow the particularized study of a given car necessary to identify it as a possible carrier of illegal aliens.  Such a requirement also would largely eliminate any deterrent to the conduct of well disguised smuggling operations
column2: even though smugglers are known to use these highways regularly.  Pp.  428 U. S. 556-557.

column1: (b) While the need to make routine checkpoint stops is great
column2: the consequent intrusion on Fourth Amendment interests is quite limited
column3: the interference with legitimate traffic being minimal and checkpoint operations involving less discretionary enforcement activity than roving patrol stops.  Pp.  428 U. S. 557-560.

column1: (c) Under the circumstances of these checkpoint stops
column2: which do not involve searches
column3: the Government or public interest in making such stops outweighs the constitutionally protected interest of the private citizen.  Pp.  428 U. S. 560-562.

column1: (d) With respect to the checkpoint involved in No 74-1560
column2: it is constitutional to refer motorists selectively to a secondary inspection area for limited inquiry on the basis of criteria that would not sustain a roving patrol stop
column3: since the intrusion is sufficiently minimal that no particularized reason need exist to justify it.  Pp.  428 U. S. 563-564.

column1: 2. Operation of a fixed checkpoint need not be authorized in advance by a judicial warrant.  Camara v. Municipal Court

column1: Petitioner was found guilty of first-degree murder and sentenced to death under amended Louisiana statutes enacted after this Court's decision in Furman v. Georgia
column2: 408 U. S. 238.  The Louisiana Supreme Court affirmed
column3: rejecting petitioner's contention that the new procedure for imposing the death penalty is unconstitutional.  The post-Furman legislation mandates imposition of the death penalty whenever
column4: with respect to five categories of homicide (here
column5: killing during the perpetration of an armed robbery)
column6: the jury finds the defendant had a specific intent to kill or to inflict great bodily harm.  If a verdict of guilty of first-degree murder is returned
column7: death is mandated regardless of any mercy recommendation.  Every jury is instructed on the crimes of second-degree murder and manslaughter and permitted to consider those verdicts even if no evidence supports the lesser verdicts; and

column1: As part of a complex plan for ridding the State of abandoned automobiles
column2: a Maryland statute provided that anyone in possession of an inoperable automobile over eight years old (""hulk"") could transfer it to a licensed scrap processor
column3: who then could claim a ""bounty"" from the State for its destruction
column4: without delivery to the processor or subsequent submission to the State of any documentation of title.  In 1974
column5: the statute was amended to require a processor to submit title documentation in order to receive a bounty.  But the documentation requirements differ as between a processor with a plant in Maryland and an out-of-state processor.  The former need only submit an ""indemnity agreement"" in which an unlicensed hulk supplier certifies his own right to the hulk and agrees to indemnify the processor for any third-party claims arising from its destruction; the non-Maryland processor must submit either a certificate of title
column7: or a bill of sale from a police auction.  Appellee is a Virginia processor participating in the Maryland plan whose supply of bounty-eligible hulks received from Maryland sources declined after enactment of the 1974 amendment.  Appellee brought suit claiming that the amendment violated the Commerce Clause
column8: and denied appellee equal protection of the laws.  A three-judge District Court granted summary judgment for appellee
column9: and enjoined Maryland from giving further effect to the part of the 1974 amendment that restricts the right to obtain bounties based on indemnity agreements to Maryland processors only.

column1: 1. The amendment does not constitute an impermissible burden on interstate commerce in violation of the Commerce Clause.  Pp.  426 U. S. 802-810.

(a) Maryland's amendment of its statute was not the kind of action with which the Commerce Clause is concerned.  Maryland has not sought to prohibit the interstate flow of hulks or to regulate the conditions under which the flow may occur
column2: but

has entered into the market itself by offering bounties to bid up the price of hulks; an impact on interstate commerce has occurred only because the amendment made it more lucrative for unlicensed suppliers to dispose of their hulks in Maryland instead of taking them out of the State.  Pp.  426 U. S. 804-806.

column1: (b) Nothing in the purposes of the Commerce Clause forbids a State's entry into the market as purchaser of potential articles of interstate commerce where the State restricts its trade to its own citizens.  Although the practical effect of the 1974 amendment was to channel the benefits of the bounties to domestic processors
column2: no trade barrier of the type forbidden by the Commerce Clause impedes movement of hulks out of the State.  Pp.  426 U. S. 807-810.

column1: 2. Nor does the 1974 amendment deny appellee equal protection of the laws.  The amendment's distinction between domestic and foreign scrap processors
column2: complemented by the reasonable assumptions that hulks delivered to Maryland processors are likely to have been abandoned in Maryland
column3: and those delivered to non-Maryland processors are likely to have been abandoned outside Maryland
column4: bears a rational relationship to the basic statutory purpose of using state funds to clear Maryland's landscape of abandoned automobiles.  That is all the Constitution requires in the case of economic legislation.  That Maryland might have furthered its underlying purpose more artfully
column5: more directly
column6: or more completely does not warrant a conclusion that the method it chose is unconstitutional.  Pp.  426 U. S. 810-814.

column2: reversed.

|426 u.s. 833|National League of Cities v. Usery

The Fair Labor Standards Act was amended in 1974 so as to extend the Act's minimum wage and maximum hour provisions to almost all employees of States and their political subdivisions.  Appellants (including a number of cities and States) in these cases brought an action against appellee Secretary of Labor challenging the validity of these 1974 amendments and seeking declaratory and injunctive relief.  A three-judge District Court dismissed the complaint for failure to state a claim upon which relief might be granted.
1. Insofar as the 1974 amendments operate directly to displace the States' abilities to structure employer employee relationships in areas of traditional governmental functions
column2: such as fire prevention
column3: police protection
column5: public health
column7: they are not within the authority granted Congress by the Commerce Clause.  In attempting to exercise its Commerce Clause power to prescribe minimum wages and maximum hours to be paid by the States in their sovereign capacities
column8: Congress has sought to wield its power in a fashion that would impair the States' ""ability to function effectively in a federal system
column12: and this exercise of congressional authority does not comport with the federal system of government embodied in the Constitution.  Pp.  426 U. S. 840-852.

column1: 2. Congress may not exercise its power to regulate commerce so as to force directly upon the States its choices as to how essential decisions regarding the conduct of integral governmental functions are to be made.  Fry v. United States
column2: supra
column3: distinguished; Maryland v. Wirtz
column5: overruled.  Pp.  426 U. S. 852-855.

column2: reversed and remanded.

column1: As a result of certain information concerning respondent's participation in an attempted sale of heroin
column2: he was subpoenaed to testify before a grand jury investigating narcotics traffic in the area.  The prosecutor warned him that he was not required to answer any questions that might incriminate him
column3: that all other questions had to be answered truthfully or else he would be subject to a charge of perjury
column5: if he desired a lawyer he could have one
column6: but that the lawyer could not be inside the grand jury room.  Subsequently
column7: respondent was charged with perjury for admittedly false statements made to the grand jury about his involvement in the attempted heroin sale.  The District Court granted respondent's motion to suppress his grand jury testimony because he was not given the warnings called for by Miranda v. Arizona
column9: holding that respondent was a ""putative"" or ""virtual"" defendant when called before the grand jury
column10: and therefore entitled to full Miranda warnings.  The Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held:  The judgment is reversed and the case is remanded.  Pp.  425 U. S. 571-584;  425 U. S. 584-609; 609.

column2: reversed and remanded.
joined by MR. JUSTICE WHITE
column3: MR. JUSTICE POWELL
column5: concluded that Miranda warnings need not be given to a grand jury witness who is called to testify about criminal activities in which he may have been personally involved
column6: and that therefore the failure to give such warnings is no basis for having false statements made to the grand jury suppressed in a subsequent prosecution of the witness for perjury based on those statements.  Pp.  425 U. S. 571-584.

column2: joined by MR. JUSTICE MARSHALL
column3: concluded that
column4: even when the privilege against compulsory self-incrimination is implicated
column5: when false answers are given
column6: the witness may consistently with the Fifth Amendment privilege be prosecuted for perjury; that
column7: in the circumstances of this case
column8: respondent's false answers were not induced by governmental tactics so unfair as to constitute prosecution for perjury a violation of the

column1: Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment; that
column2: in the absence of a knowing waiver of the privilege against compulsory self-incrimination
column3: the Fifth Amendment requires that testimony obtained by calling a putative defendant before a grand jury and compelling him to testify regarding the suspected crime be unavailable as evidence in a later prosecution for that crime; and that
column4: given the potential prejudice to a putative defendant's privilege against compulsory self-incrimination when called and compelled to testify before a grand jury and the ability of counsel to help avoid that prejudice
column5: some guidance by counsel is required.  Pp.  425 U. S. 584-609.

column2: joined by MR. JUSTICE BLACKMUN
column3: concluded that the Fifth Amendment privilege against compulsory self-incrimination did not require the suppression of the respondent's grand jury testimony
column4: since that testimony was relevant only to his prosecution for perjury
column5: and was not introduced in the prosecution for attempting to distribute heroin
column6: and that this was not a case where it could plausibly be argued that the perjury prosecution must be barred because of prosecutorial conduct amounting to a denial of due process.  P.  425 U. S. 609.

column9: since it does not explain whether a ""recognized charitable cause"" means one recognized by the Internal Revenue Service as tax exempt

column2: but further provides that
column3: 50 years after approval of the Act

column5: and that the ""unallotted lands"" shall be ""subject to the control and management thereof as Congress may deem expedient for the benefit of said Indians.""  In 1968
column6: Congress amended the Act to reserve the mineral rights ""in perpetuity for the benefit of the Tribe
column7: subject to a prior judicial determination that the allottees had not been granted vested rights to the mineral deposits by the Act.  As authorized by the 1968 amendment
column8: the Tribe brought suit against the allottees to determine whether the allottees
column10: had received a vested property right in the minerals under the Act.  The District Court held that the Act did not grant the allottees vested rights in the mineral deposits
column11: construing ""unallotted lands"" in  3 as including such deposits.  The Court of Appeals reversed
column13: noncontingent grant of the mineral deposits to the allottees
column14: in the absence of any express statement of Congress' intent to retain power over the deposits.

column1: Held:  The Act did not give the allottees of surface lands vested rights in the mineral deposits underlying those lands.  This reading of the Act is supported by its legislative history

column3: and thereby relinquish ""control and management thereof as Congress may deem expedient for the benefit of said Indians."" column1: Six years after his conviction for felony murder from which he took no appeal
column2: petitioner sought collateral relief from the state court on the ground
column3: inter alia
column4: that Negroes had been excluded from the grand jury that indicted him.  Relief was denied on the ground that petitioner's failure to raise the claim before trial constituted a waiver of that claim under state law.  Petitioner then sought habeas corpus in the District Court
column5: which granted relief.  The Court of Appeals reversed
column6: relying on Davis v. United States
column8: which held that a federal prisoner who had failed to timely challenge the allegedly unconstitutional composition of the grand jury that indicted him could not
column10: attack the grand jury's composition in an action for federal collateral relief.

column1: Held:  The Court of Appeals correctly held that the Davis rule
column2: which requires not only a showing of ""cause"" for the defendant's failure to challenge the composition of the grand jury before trial
column3: but also a showing of actual prejudice
column4: applies with equal force when a federal court is asked in a habeas corpus proceeding to overturn a state court conviction because of an allegedly unconstitutional grand jury indictment.  The Louisiana time limitation was designed to serve the same important purposes of sound judicial administration as were stressed in Davis
column5: supra at  411 U. S. 241
column6: and considerations of comity and federalism require that those purposes be accorded no less recognition when a federal court is asked to overturn a state conviction than when it is asked to overturn a federal conviction because of an allegedly unconstitutional grand jury indictment.  Pp.  425 U. S. 538-542.

The ground for the injunction was not that  16.01 was unconstitutional
column2: but that the local officials had acted in bad faith and unconstitutionally in using that statute (which the District Court found could ""by no stretch of the imagination"" be read as applying) as a pretext for forcing appellee to stop exhibiting the film
column3: without any design to convict him on the felony charge.  Since a three-judge court was therefore not required
column4: the appeal should have been taken to the Court of Appeals.

column5: and this distinction is one of considerable significance

column2: dress

column1: Tribal Court of the Northern Cheyenne Tribe held to have exclusive jurisdiction over an adoption proceeding arising on the Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation in which all parties are members of the Tribe residing on the reservation.

(a) Montana state court jurisdiction over such a proceeding would interfere with the powers of self-government conferred upon the Tribe by federal law and exercised through the Tribal Court; would subject a dispute arising on the reservation among reservation Indians to a forum other than the one they have established for themselves; and
column2: as the record in this case indicates
column3: would risk conflicting adjudications affecting the custody of the child sought to be adopted
column4: and would correspondingly diminish the tribal court's authority.

column1: (b) No federal statute sanctions such interference with tribal self-government.  Title 25 U.S.C.  372a
column2: which is concerned solely with the documentation necessary to prove adoption by an Indian in proceedings before the Secretary of the Interior
column3: and which recognizes adoption ""by a judgment or decree of a State court"" as one means of documentation
column4: nowhere addresses the jurisdiction of state courts to render such judgments or decrees.

column1: (c) Even assuming that the Montana courts properly exercised jurisdiction over Indian adoptions prior to the organization of the Tribe
column2: that jurisdiction has now been preempted by creation of a Tribal Court with jurisdiction over adoptions pursuant to the Indian Reorganization Act of 1934.

column1: (d) Denying tribal member plaintiffs access to Montana courts in adoption proceedings does not constitute impermissible racial discrimination
column2: since (1) the Tribal Court's exclusive jurisdiction derives not from the plaintiffs' race
column3: but from the Tribe's quasi-sovereign status under federal law
column4: and (2) even if a jurisdictional holding occasionally denies an Indian plaintiff a forum to which a non-Indian has access
column5: such disparate treatment of the Indian

column1: is justified as a benefit to the class of which he is a member by furthering the congressional policy of Indian self-government.

But under  109(a)(3) a penalty may be assessed only after the operator

column2: Inc. v. Provident Securities Co.
a personal holding company contemplating liquidation
column3: sold assets to petitioner corporation.  Respondent received from petitioner as part of the purchase price convertible debentures which
column4: if converted into petitioner's common stock
column5: would make respondent a holder of more than 10% of petitioner's outstanding common stock.  A few days later
column7: one of the debentures was sold to a group of underwriters for cash in an amount exceeding its face value.  After making debenture and cash distributions to its stockholders
column8: respondent dissolved.  Under  16(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (Act) a corporation may recover for itself the profits realized by an officer
column10: or beneficial owner of more than 10% of its shares from a purchase and sale of its stock within a six-month period.  An exemptive provision specifies
column12: that  16(b) shall not be construed to cover any transaction where the beneficial owner was not such both ""at the time of"" the purchase and sale of the securities involved.  Since the amount of petitioner's debentures received by respondent was large enough to make respondent a beneficial owner of petitioner within the meaning of  16
column13: and its disposal of the securities within the six-month period exposed respondent to a suit by petitioner to recover profits realized by respondent on the sale to the underwriters
column14: respondent sought a declaratory judgment of its nonliability under  16(b).  The District Court granted summary judgment to respondent
column15: and the Court of Appeals affirmed

column1: Held:  By virtue of the exemptive provision
